Posts.Content: Nanalinda wrote: In July of 06, I found a lump in my left breast while in the shower.  Everything has gone down hill since then.  Lumpectomy in Septmber and chemo started Nov. 1st 06, TAC every three weeks x6, followed by radiation.  Then came the waiting game.  I knew that with TNBC there was a risk of reocurrence, but I hoped it would not happen to me.  I got back to living life, and finally got to the point where my first thought in the morning was no longer "OMG I have cancer."  In July of 08, my left arm swelled.  I thought I had lymphedema, but my physician ordered an ultrasound to r/o a blood clot in my arm.  It was then they discovered multiple enlarged lymph nodes in my left shoulder and surrounding my clavicle.  The PET scan verified this as mets, and also discovered an 8cm mass of nodes in the middle of my chest as well as an area in my 4th thoracic spine that lit up (bone scan was negative).  On August 1st I started Taxol/Avastin 3 weeks on and 1 week off.  The palpable mass in my neck has gone down, so I know there has been some improvement.  I have finished 6 months of chemo, and my oncologist wants to give me a break now.  Of course I am nervous stopping chemo for fear of what will happen while I am off.  I am scheduled for a PET scan 1/19 to see how things look.  We did recently discover through MRI of my back that the spot on my T4 is Mets (it turns out certain mets do not show up on bone scan).  I will be starting Zometa on 1/29.  I want to say that I have been viewing the posts on this site for awhile and it has helped me get through some rough times in the last few months.  I finally got up the nerve to join so I can participate with such a wonderful group of women.  I hope to be able to help others myself as you all have helped me.  Linda Dx 7/26/2006, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 11:19AM Nanalinda wrote: I know what you're saying Watson.  I only get my steroids once a week with my Gemzar dose, but they make me eat like crazy for 3 days.  When I first started on Gemzar, I was losing weight (an average of about a lb a week), now I am gaining about a lb a week.  Not good.  I also noticed that the food I crave is food that is not good for me.  I try to eat healthier once the steroid feasting has subsided.
Posts.Title: Steroids and Girl Scout Cookies Nanalinda KSkier

Posts.Content: Nanalinda wrote: Well, I had my weekly chemo yesterday including my lovely dose of Decadron.  Those of you who receive steroids know that they tend to make you eat a little more than usual.  In fact, I tell my family "don't get too close because I may eat you!"  Well, last night my granddaughter delivered the girl scout cookies I had ordered from her.  Yummo!!!  So it didn't take long for me to crack open a box of Caramel DeLites (they are my favorite) and I had one, then another, and another.  I could have easily eaten the whole box last evening, but I finally came out of my eating frenzy, closed the box and put them away.  They keep calling to me, and I am sure that after I eat a healthy lunch, I will have to finish off that box of cookies.  Did I tell you I ordered 6 boxes of cookies from my granddaughter?  I guess I will have to share some with my husband... that is if he can get to them fast enough!! Posts.Content: Nanalinda wrote: Now that I am stage IV, I spend a lot of time thinking about my life (past and future).  When I was in high school, I wanted to be a lawyer.  Instead, I met my soul mate and instead of going to college, I married him 6 months after graduation (I was 18).  We just celebrated our 35th anniversary and are still very happy.  We have 4 great kids and 5 adorable grandchildren and I am happy with my life the way it is, but I do sometimes wonder what it would be like if I followed my dream and went to law school.  Would he have waited for me and would we still have married?  I ended up going to nursing school locally and have enjoyed being a nurse and I know I made a difference in many lives and even saved a few lives during my nursing career.  The last few years of my career, I became the Director of Quality Management which had many responsibilities, one of which included Risk Management, so I was working very closely with Attorneys and I loved it.  It made me wonder again what if..... Now I am no longer working, so it is a non-issue, but I still wonder.  I guess it isn't so much a regret as a "I wonder if" issue. Some regrets I do have:  I wish I had taken better care of my health when I was younger;  I wish I hadn't smoked when I did (although there is no correlation between smoking and BC);  I wish I hadn't worked night shift all those years (increases risk of cancer). Do any of you have regrets or stories of "I wonder if?"  Linda Dx 7/26/2006, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2009 09:39AM Nanalinda wrote: I just had similar results in my PET scan; some of my spine tumors had shrunk and showed less activity, while one grew and was more active.  I asked my oncologist why this would happen.  She said that sometimes the cells in one tumor will become resistant to the chemo, while the other tumors do not.  She said they don't know why this happens, but she has seen it many times.  My GP also said that there is less blood flow to bone, which can inhibit the the chemo getting to the bone.  Hope this helps.  Linda

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 06:40AM Nanalinda wrote: konakat:  Not bitch 6  bitch 0 I always love your posts, and you always have so much to offer these boards.  I understand where you are coming from with this post.  We metser's are fighting a totally different battle from the early stagers.  I understand that they are trying to cheer us on and to help in there own way... but my biggest peeve is when they respond with the "keep the positive attitude" or "stay positive."  I was my own cheerleader before I was dx with mets.... I had the positive attitude and it did nothing to protect me.  Now that I have mets, I too try to live in denial, but when we lose another sister, that denial is ripped away from me and I am reminded that I too am dying.  I have been living with mets for a little over a year now, and I have not yet had a good PET and it scares the shit out of me.  I always wonder "how long do I have?"  I too hope that I can make it to that 5 year mark or longer, and I hope all of my sisters on this board do too.  That is a lot to hope for, but hope is the one thing that keeps me from the depths of depression.  This is the only board I really feel comfortable in because everyone else here is dealing with the same fear that I live with.  I try to go over to the triple negative board, but it is right now so full of the "stay positive" "rah rah rah" posts, that I don't feel I can post there for fear of bringing them down.  I just ask that we don't have to see "stay positive" on our stage IV board.  It is so inappropriate.  No, konakat:  you are not a bitch.... you are frightened, just like the rest of us.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 10:00AM Nanalinda wrote: Do you have short term disability available through your employer?  I was able to draw 1/2 disability along with 1/2 acumulated sick time in order to continue to be paid for the required 5 month waiting period.  You can ask your Dr. to take you off work and get the disability going, then apply for SSDI which you automatically qualify for with stage IV cancer.  Check with your HR department to see how long you can be off on disability as some will end your employment after 3 months.  I was lucky as our policy allowed me to continue employement for the full 6 months.  Good luck to you.  I know that for me, going off work was the best decision I made.  I feel so much better, and can spend more time with my family.  I have worked for the last 30 years, looking forward to retirement and decided I wasn't going to allow cancer to cheat me out of my retirement.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2010 02:06AM Nanalinda wrote: There are two different kinds of bone mets... Osteoblastic and Osteolytic.  The osteoblastic grows on to the bone, and the osteolytic eats away the bone.  Osteolytic bone mets does not show up on bone scans, but it will show up on PET scan or MRI.  My bone scan was negative, but my bone mets was found on my PET scan.  My bone mets are osteolytic.  At first, I had no pain from the bone mets, then I soon started to feel a burning pain in my back which eventually worsened.  Ask if you can have a PET scan to verify bone mets and to see if you have mets anywhere else in your body.  Best of luck to you.  Linda

Posts.Content: Nanalinda wrote: Well...  One of my onc nurses is going on a medical mission to some 3rd world country, and she needs to raise some of the money for her trip.  One of the things she is doing is having a bake sale at the hospital tomorrow.  I told her I would bring in something so I made a pecan coffee cake.  I thought I should take something else, and I thought it would be nice to make some candy apples for the bake sale and some for my grand kids.  So...  I went to the store to buy all of the ingredients, including $15 worth of apples and a candy thermometer.  I have never made candy apples before, so I followed a recipe, mixed it all together and started cooking it on the stove.  The recipe said to boil it on medium until it reached 302 degrees F.  I started it on medium, and once it started to boil, it only went as high as 150 degrees, so I turned the fire up a little.  It went up to 175, then no higher so I turned it up a little more which brought it up to 200, then it stayed there.  I boiled a little longer and turned it up again and the highest the thermometer would go was 200 degrees...  so I turned the fire up some more.  Next thing I knew, smoke was billowing out of the pan, and there was this gawd-awful smell!  My red candy had turned black.  I burned the candy, and I think I ruined my pan.  It took awhile to get the smoke out of my kitchen, but that awful smell is still here.  I guess I won't be taking candy apples to the bake sale!  I wonder if the thermometer was faulty?  I thought you all could use a good laugh!  Have a good night!! Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 03:31PM Nanalinda wrote: JJC44:  I am so sorry you have to join our mets group, it is OK to be scared; we have all been there.  I too am TN with mets to lymph nodes near clavicle, and mediastinum; also in spine.  I have not yet been on Xeloda or Ixempra, but I have been on Zometa for a little over a year now.  There are many different chemos out there for TNBC, and different oncs. start with different meds for their patients.  I started with Taxol/Avastin which worked for about 10 months, then I went to Gemzar which worked for 6 months, and I recently started on Navelbine.  The key is to find what works and stick with it for as long as you can, then go on to the next.  The chemos that I have been on have had minimal s/e's and provide decent QOL which is important to me.  I was dx with mets in July 08, so have been living with it for almost 2 years now.  I ended up having rads to my spine this past Dec. d'/t pain, but now I am pain free.  Stick with the boards; there is lots of good information here.  Keep us up to date with how you are doing.  Feel free to pm me if you want to talk.  Linda

Posts.Content: Nanalinda wrote: I want to tell you a tale that is a little creepy, but it is a true story. I was working as an RN at a small hospital in my home town. I began working as the hospital Infection Control Nurse in 1998, which involved getting my own office on the 3rd floor of the hospital in an area that used to be patient rooms. In 1999 one of our secretaries developed Non Hodgkin's Lymphoma (she was 29), and she passed away that year. In 2002, another one of our secretaries developed breast cancer, she was treated for it and is doing fine now. In 2005, my boss, who was the Medical Director of the hospital (family practice physician), 54 and a health nut all her life, a vegetarian since she was 20; was dx with stage 4 colon cancer. She passed away in 2008. I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2006, and mets in 2008. A man who worked on the same floor, and just a few offices down from us, was diagnosed with throat cancer in 2007; the kind you get from smoking, but he had never had a cigarette in his life. His treatment nearly killed him, but he survived and is still suffering side effects from the rads he underwent. So, out of the 7 of us that worked on that floor; 5 developed cancer, and two died from it (I will most likely succumb from my cancer eventually). They eventually moved us all off that floor in to new offices, and brought in "experts" to do air testing which found nothing unusual. So was it all just a terrible coincidence or was there something on that floor causing the cancers? We will never know. I try not to dwell in the past, but we all wonder what may have caused our cancer, and I still wonder some times if I would have gotten it still if I had not worked on that floor for so many years. They have since put a physician office practice up on that floor of the hospital, and as far as I know, no one else has been diagnosed with cancer up there. Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 06:56PM Nanalinda wrote: Hi everyone, another RN here.  I graduated from a diploma program in 1984, and have worked at the same small hospital for all of my career.  I have worked in med/surg, dialysis and ICU, then I went on to be the Infection Control Nurse, then Director of Quality Management and Risk Manager.  I am now on SSDI due to extreme exhaustion from the weekly chemo.  I miss working, but really had no choice but to go off on disability.  I give you girls who are still working a lot of credit (especially those who are in direct patient care).  Nursing is not easy, especially these days.  I am really surprised at the number of nurses there are here with BC.  I am another one who worked nights for many years; I have read many times that night shift work can cause many serious health problems, and wonder if it may have contributed to my BC.  My best friend who worked right along side me for many of those nights also had BC.  She had treatment and is now 10 years out and doing well.  I was originally diagnosed in 2006, and developed mets in 2008.  Now it is treatment for life.  My Dr's are wonderful and treat me with respect.  I have worked with them for many years and in fact my oncologist was on my Patient Quality of Care Committee when I was diagnosed.  He was very upset when my mets was diagnosed and said to me "why did this have to happen to you."  I was very touched by his concern.

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 07:07PM Nanalinda wrote: Raro:  Great news from the CT scan.  Regarding the white blood cells;  I had the same problem on Gemzar.  I started taking Neupogen, an injection I give myself at home after chemo.  It has brought my WBC's back up to normal level.  The Neupogen can cause some body aches which I had the first week, but I have had no further problems since then.  When I was on Avastin; my BP and heart rate went up and my Dr. started me on Atenolol which controlled my BP.  I stopped Avastin about 4 months ago, but I am still on the Atenolol as my BP is maintaining on it.  I have had no SE's from it at all.  Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Nanalinda wrote: When I looked at my previous thread on regrets, I realized I caused a lot of sadness for my breast sisters, and I feel bad.  I am very sorry.  I thought I could counteract that by posting a thread on how we made a difference in someone elses life.  In my regret's thread, I talked about becoming a nurse rather than a lawyer, and even though I wonder "what if" I became a lawyer, I am glad I became a nurse.  I know I made a difference many times.  One story that stands out happened many years ago when I worked in the Intensive Care Unit.  We had a patient who was mentally handicapped about 50 or 60 years old, he was a "frequent flyer" or someone who was admitted frequently.  This man had heart problems, and we knew that he probably would not survive this admission.  He had no friends or family, no one ever came to visit him.  He was a DNR which meant no resuscitation if his heart failed.  His condition was becoming worse, and he was frightened and crying; this particular night was not as busy as other nights, so I spent as much time in his room as I could.  When I knew he was getting close, I sat at his bedside and held his hand and spoke to him calmly until he passed.  All I could think of was "what if this were my father or my brother", I couldn't let him pass alone and frightened.  I know I made a difference for a man who lived a sad and lonely life. Have you made a difference in someones life?  A friend, family, or stranger?  Tell us your story. Dx 7/26/2006, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 08:48PM Nanalinda wrote: Kirby:  Just as you said;  it is the "not knowing" that is so hard to deal with.  Our future has been changed, but we don't know how.  What we do know is that we have a disease that is supposed to kill us at some time... what we don't know is when.  Chemo is do-able, and you can have a good life while going through it.  Every day we survive brings us one day closer to the cure.  You will have days where death seems to stare you in the face, and you will feel depressed, but you will climb out of that depression and carry on.  Just don't let the depression control your life (there are pills for that).  Your life has changed, and you will continue to feel many emotions because of it, but try to live your life the best you can, and never give up on hope.  I hope every day that there will be a cure soon, or something that will make this a chronic disease.  Best of luck.  Linda

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 08:21AM Nanalinda wrote: Kirby:  I am very sorry you had to join our group, but I want to welcome you.  The other girls above have pretty much answered your questions.  I remember when I was told I had mets in July of last year... I thought it was the end of my world.  All I could think was "I am going to die."  I have since been on treatment for a year.  Other than some fatigue, I feel pretty good.  I am learning to live as a metser, and our sisters on these threads provide a lot of support for us "newbies".  Please keep us up to date on how you are doing, and don't hesitate to ask any questions you may have.  Todays appointment may be very emotional, I hope you have someone going with you for support.  Best of luck.  Linda

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2010 07:30AM Nanalinda wrote: I have been dealing with mets for almost 2 years now, and I have a hard time crying when I need to... I find it painful; my eyes burn and my head hurts so I make myself stop as soon as it starts.  I wish I could have a good cry as I think it is healthy as long as you don't over do it.  It is so hard dealing with mets and the thought that our lives will be shorter because of it.  I get sad and angry thinking about it... I have so much to live for and want to live a long time.  I too get hopeful that they will find a cure for us soon and this nightmare will go away.  Hang on to hope, because when you lose hope, you lose your reason to live.

Posts.Content: Nanalinda wrote: I am so grateful to see another year.  I was 48 when I was first diagnosed, and today I am 53.  I have been living with mets for a little over a year now.  I certainly look at each day differently now, and really appreciate my birthday.  I wanted to share this with my friends here on the boards as I am sure you all can relate to my desire to see many more birthdays to come.  My 4 children, their spouses and my 5 grandchildren are all coming by this eve so we can celebrate.  I need to go now so I can take a nap before they come.  Dx 7/26/2006, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
